Situation1: Laundry piles up, but someone eventually finds time to fold it.
Expectation2: Deliver packages on time and to the correct address
Situation2: A medical supply delivery must reach a hospital department on schedule to ensure patient care
Story: I stare at the mountain of laundry on the couch, the colors and whites all jumbled together, waiting for me. My partner’s been hinting all week—“Maybe we can fold it together tonight?”—but every night, I’m either too tired or running late. Today, I promised I’d get it done before dinner. But just as I reach for the first shirt, my phone buzzes: urgent delivery, medical supplies, hospital drop-off, must arrive within the hour. I know what’s at stake—someone’s care, maybe even their life, depends on me getting there on time. But I also know what’s at stake at home. My partner’s patience is wearing thin, and I can’t keep letting them down. My chest tightens as I glance between the laundry and my delivery bag. Both roles demand my attention, both feel equally important, and I can’t see how to do right by both.
